humanum_full_description_en:
Wang Yun's "Shuowen Shirui": "In fact, "Guang" sees its three sides with one wall. "Liu" sees its four sides with two walls. The middle and high ones are the poles, and the left and right kills are the two universes." See "å®€".

"Shuowen": "Guang, because it is a house, it looks like a high house. Wherever it belongs, it is from Guang. It is read as if you read it." Xu Kai "Shuowen Jiezi Annotation": "" ã€It is said that the " ï¸¿ " on the house is relative. "

A and Bronze inscriptions do not see a separate " Guang ", but they are useful parts. "å®€" and "å¹¿" are commonly used as bronze inscription parts, see " miao ", "åº¿", " fu " and " guang ".

" Guang " is different from " factory ". " Guang " is like a house, and " factory " is the same as the oracle " stone ", like cliffs and rocks. But " wide ", " plant " as the inscriptions part, because sometimes mixed shape near, see " factory ", " stone ." In addition, "å¹¿" is a simplified word for modern "å¹¿", see "å¹¿".

Qiu Xigui pointed out that if the building referred to is relatively simple, or is not mainly for people to live in, the font is often from " wide ", such as " lu ", " lang ", "åº‘", " fu ", " library ", etc. In simplified characters, the word " guang " is sometimes simplified as " factory ", such as " kitchen ", " stable ", " toilet ", etc. The simplified version of the simplified character " Factory " is called " Factory ", which is also from "å¹¿" (the simplified character " Factory " and "åˆ" in the initial text " Factory " are also the same form).
